  "description": "The Shawshank Redemption is a movie starring Tim Robbins, Morgan Freeman, and Bob Gunton. Two imprisoned men bond over a number of years, finding solace and eventual redemption through acts of common decency.",
  "datePublished": "1994-09-23",

  "review": {
    "@type": "Review",
    "itemReviewed": {
      "@type": "CreativeWork",
      "url": "/title/tt0111161/"
    },
    "author": {
      "@type": "Person",

    "dateCreated": "2008-02-18",
    "inLanguage": "English",
    "name": "This is How Movies Should Be Made",
    "reviewBody": "This movie is not your ordinary Hollywood flick. It has a great and deep message. This movie has a foundation and just kept on being built on from their and that foundation is hope.\n\nOther than just the message of this movie the acting was phenomenal. Tim Robbins gave one of the greatest performances ever. He was inspiring, intelligent and most of all positive. His performance just made me smile. Robbins plays Andy Dufresne who was wrongfully convicted of murdering his wife and her lover. He is gets to life sentences but yet never gives up hope. In he becomes friends with Ellis Boyd \"Red\" Redding played by Morgan Freeman. Freeman who gives the finest performance of his career has unlike Robbins lost hope. He is in deep regret of the crime that he committed. His way of deflecting the pain away is by trying to not feel anything at all. With his friendship with Andy he learns that without our hopes and dreams we have nothing. Andy also becomes friends with the rest of Red\u0027s group. James Whitmore also gave a great performance as Brooks Halten who gets out of prison parole but in the words of Red he has been \"institutionalized\". \n\nThe directing by Frank Darabont was just magnificent. He kept this movie at a great steady pace along with the writing and great cinematography. He portrayed prison life in such a horrifying way, but not in terms of the physical pain but the stress and pain that wares mentally on the inmates, some of which deserve a second chance. \n\nWhatever you do, don\u0027t listen to the people who say this movie is overrated because this is one of the most inspiring and greatest movies ever. It has everything you could possibly want.",

                <span>    Chronicles the experiences of a formerly successful banker as a prisoner in the gloomy jailhouse of Shawshank after being found guilty of a crime he did not commit.         <h2>Did You Know?</h2>
    <div id="trivia" class="txt-block">
        <h4>Trivia</h4>
    Symbolic references can be found in many areas of the movie. For example, Red's full name is Ellis Redding. Ellis is a Welsh derivative of "elus" meaning "kindly, benevolent" and Redding as a Germanic surname means "counsel, advice" (Ellis Redding = "benevolent counselor"). Andy Dufresne has the symbolism of being the savior for many inmates in the prison. Andy's name (Andrew) means "brave, strong, courageous", and his initials are A. D. (anno Domini, "the year of our lord"). Andy's main antagonist is the Warden who is symbolized as the devil (Lucifer means "bringer of light"). When asked what his favorite passage in the Bible is, he references "I am the light of the world..."        <a href="trivia"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>
                <hr />
     <div id="goofs"  class="txt-block">
        <h4>Goofs</h4>
Andy is introduced to the library by Brooks in 1949. Brooks points out a Louis L'Amour section, but L'Amour's first book under his own name wasn't published until 1953 (he had written a series of Hopalong Cassidy novels in the late 1940s under the name Tex Burns), and didn't produce enough books to warrant his own section until the 1960's. He was still somewhat known having written many short stories for pulp magazines, but these featured many writers and stories. Brooks also points out a section of Reader's Digest Condensed Books, which were first published in 1950.        <a href="trivia?tab=gf"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>   
                <hr />
    <div id="quotes" class="text-block">
        <h4>Quotes</h4>
[<span class="fine">first lines</span>]
<br /><a href="/name/nm0218810/"
><span class="character">District Attorney</span></a>:
Mr. Dufresne, describe the confrontation you had with your wife the night that she was murdered.
<br /><a href="/name/nm0000209/"
><span class="character">Andy Dufresne</span></a>:
It was very bitter. She said she was glad I knew, that she hated all the sneaking around. And she said that she wanted a divorce in Reno.

class="nobr" >See more</a> »

    <div class="article" id="titleUserReviewsTeaser">
        <h2>User Reviews</h2>
        <div class="user-comments">
                    <div class="tinystarbar" title="10/10">
                        <div style="width: 100px;"> </div>
                    </div>
                <span>
                    <strong>This is How Movies Should Be Made</strong>
                    <div class="comment-meta">
                        18 February 2008 | by <a href="/user/ur16117882/"
><span>alexkolokotronis</span></a>
                        – <a href="/user/ur16117882/comments"
>See all my reviews</a>
                    </div>
                    <div>
                        <p>This movie is not your ordinary Hollywood flick. It has a great and deep message. This movie has a foundation and just kept on being built on from their and that foundation is hope.<br/><br/>Other than just the message of this movie the acting was phenomenal. Tim Robbins gave one of the greatest performances ever. He was inspiring, intelligent and most of all positive. His performance just made me smile. Robbins plays Andy Dufresne who was wrongfully convicted of murdering his wife and her lover. He is gets to life sentences but yet never gives up hope. In he becomes friends with Ellis Boyd "Red" Redding played by Morgan Freeman. Freeman who gives the finest performance of his career has unlike Robbins lost hope. He is in deep regret of the crime that he committed. His way of deflecting the pain away is by trying to not feel anything at all. With his friendship with Andy he learns that without our hopes and dreams we have nothing. Andy also becomes friends with the rest of Red's group. James Whitmore also gave a great performance as Brooks Halten who gets out of prison parole but in the words of Red he has been "institutionalized". <br/><br/>The directing by Frank Darabont was just magnificent. He kept this movie at a great steady pace along with the writing and great cinematography. He portrayed prison life in such a horrifying way, but not in terms of the physical pain but the stress and pain that wares mentally on the inmates, some of which deserve a second chance. <br/><br/>Whatever you do, don't listen to the people who say this movie is overrated because this is one of the most inspiring and greatest movies ever. It has everything you could possibly want.</p>
                    </div>
                </span>

  "description": "The Godfather is a movie starring Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, and James Caan. The aging patriarch of an organized crime dynasty transfers control of his clandestine empire to his reluctant son.",
  "datePublished": "1972-03-24",
  "keywords": "mafia,crime family,patriarch,organized crime,rise to power",
  "aggregateRating": {
    "@type": "AggregateRating",
    "ratingCount": 1535604,
    "bestRating": "10.0",
    "worstRating": "1.0",
    "ratingValue": "9.2"
  },
  "review": {
    "@type": "Review",
    "itemReviewed": {
      "@type": "CreativeWork",
      "url": "/title/tt0068646/"
    },
    "author": {
      "@type": "Person",
      "name": "mattrochman"
    },
    "dateCreated": "2006-10-14",
    "inLanguage": "English",
    "name": "Initially, I wasn\u0027t a fan... but then I realised",
    "reviewBody": "This is a masterpiece. A timeless masterpiece. Initially, I didn\u0027t like this film all that much - I found it rather over-hyped and boring. This was until the advent of DVD, which gave me the feature I needed for this sort of film: subtitles. Once I switched them on and heard (read) every last word of Brando\u0027s ramblings and other characters ramblings, I grew a true appreciation for this epic.\n\nTo make a true epic, you need all of three following ingredients working in near perfect harmony. For screenwriters who come across this, take the following pointers on board: 1) Contrasting Characters: Good films have some character distinction, but most fall rather flat because the core of each character is the same.\n\nOf course, there are exceptions to rule (ie... where you want mono-tonal characters... aka matrix; or where you want outlandish contrasts... aka The Fifth Element), but ultimately, this is what makes films deep, meaningful and grand. Consider the contrasts between the Don\u0027s children. Michael is rather cool, rational and collected, whereas Sonny is more hot-headed, spontaneous and simple minded. But simply having these contrasts is not nearly enough. What you really need to do is to develop these characters - place them in situations - and then dwell on how their character impacts on the situation they\u0027re put in. The Godfather is a terrific example of how to pull this off. While many try to do this in screenplays, most lose the plot and create character obscurities that stretch credibility.\n\n2) Transformation: The central character(s) must undergo a transformation, resulting in them being almost unrecognizable by the end of the film. By putting them into situations, the character\u0027s character must not only influence the outcome of the situation; it must also have a lasting impact on the character. Consider Michael at the wedding and compare that to the Michael we see at the end of the film. Again, many films try, but most fail because they come up with unreal (literally, not praisingly) or simply moronic transformations (eg, Wall Street).\n\n3) Patience: Men in Black 2 was an astounding film for one simple reason - it was an entire film squashed into about 70 minutes. It was not much longer than an episode of ER or Buffy. I certainly hope the new goal of Hollywood isn\u0027t to make films as short as possible.\n\nAll the great ones spend time - time developing characters, family life, growth, patience with the story telling in general. This is the key (provided that the story isn\u0027t mind-numbingly boring). Dances with Wolves, Heat.. and so on are very patient but top-class films. While studios may be lukewarm on the idea of longer films, they are worth it if you have a ripper story to base it on.\n\nI feel that this film has not dated all that much and has tremendous re-watch-ability.",

        <h2>Storyline</h2>
        
        <div class="inline canwrap">
            <p>
                <span>    The Godfather "Don" Vito Corleone is the head of the Corleone mafia family in New York. He is at the event of his daughter's wedding. Michael, Vito's youngest son and a decorated WW II Marine is also present at the wedding. Michael seems to be uninterested in being a part of the family business. Vito is a powerful man, and is kind to all those who give him respect but is ruthless against those who do not. But when a powerful and treacherous rival wants to sell drugs and needs the Don's influence for the same, Vito refuses to do it. What follows is a clash between Vito's fading old values and the new ways which may cause Michael to do the thing he was most reluctant in doing and wage a mob war against all the other mafia families which could tear the Corleone family apart.</span>
                <em class="nobr">Written by
<a href="/search/title?plot_author=srijanarora-152-448595&view=simple&sort=alpha"
>srijanarora-152-448595</a></em>            </p>

        <h2>Did You Know?</h2>
    <div id="trivia" class="txt-block">
        <h4>Trivia</h4>
    While filming the scene in which Carlo beats her, <a href="/name/nm0001735">Talia Shire</a> lost a shoe. Not wanting to have to restore the set and wait for the camera to be set up for a second time, she simply continued to play through the scene, even at the risk of cutting her foot on all the ceramics she had just destroyed.        <a href="trivia"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>
                <hr />
     <div id="goofs"  class="txt-block">
        <h4>Goofs</h4>
In the scene when MIchael confronts Carlo about setting up Sonny, you can see a stand-in for Robert Duvall playing Tom Hagen in the background. He is kept in the background, off camera, and then blocked by Michael to obscure the fact that it is not Robert Duvall.        <a href="trivia?tab=gf"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>   
                <hr />
    <div id="quotes" class="text-block">
        <h4>Quotes</h4>
[<span class="fine">first lines</span>]
<br /><a href="/name/nm0181128/"
><span class="character">Bonasera</span></a>:
I believe in America. America has made my fortune. And I raised my daughter in the American fashion. I gave her freedom but I taught her never to dishonor her family. She found a "boy friend," not an Italian. She went to the movies with him. She stayed out late. I didn't protest. Two months ago he took her for a drive, with another boy friend. They made her drink whiskey and then they tried to take advantage of her. She resisted. She kept her honor. So they beat her. Like an animal...
<br />                [...]<br />
        <a href="trivia?tab=qt"
class="nobr" >See more</a> »
    </div>
                <hr />
     <div id="crazyCredits"  class="txt-block">
        <h4>Crazy Credits</h4>
    In the Blu-Ray version, the 2002 Paramount logo is used and tinted in sepia.        <a href="trivia?tab=cz"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>   
                <hr />
     <div id="alternateVersions"  class="txt-block">
        <h4>Alternate Versions</h4>
In 1977, a special version for television titled <a href="/title/tt0809488/">The Godfather: A Novel for Television</a> was prepared by director <a href="/name/nm0000338/">Francis Ford Coppola</a> and editor <a href="/name/nm0539794/">Barry Malkin</a> by re-editing <a href="/title/tt0068646/">The Godfather</a> and <a href="/title/tt0071562/">The Godfather: Part II</a> in chronological order and adding deleted scenes. Most of these deleted scenes are also included separately on the DVD release and in <a href="/title/tt0150742/">The Godfather Trilogy: 1901-1980</a>. Among the deleted scenes:
<ul><li>Following Bonasera's exit in the first scene, Vito whistles at Sonny for not paying attention to business.</li><li>During the wedding reception, Tom Hagen informs Don Vito that consigliere Genco won't last the night in the hospital.</li><li>After the wedding, the Don and his sons are leaving the compound with Johnny Fontane to visit Genco. Vito asks Michael if Kay was able to get home all right.</li><li>In the hospital, the Don looks at Michael's military decorations with disdain then tells Michael that he has plans for him after graduation.</li><li>A dying Genco begs Vito to stay with him believing that Vito will somehow stop his death.</li><li>An extended version of Jack Woltz's party for his child star, Janie.</li><li>After being thrown out by Woltz, Tom looks up and sees Janie crying and her mother push her back into Woltz's bedroom.</li><li>Connie and Carlo argue and she runs crying into Mama's arms. Sonny wants to confront Carlo but Vito tells him not to interfere.</li><li>After Tom returns from Hollywood, he discusses with Vito what he has discovered about Woltz.</li><li>Michael and Kay are in their hotel bed in New York City and don't want to go to the family compound. Michael has Kay call Tom pretending to be an operator, then Michael tells Tom that they are in New Hampshire and will be at the compound the next day.</li><li>On the way to meet Sollozzo, Luca sees the nightclub's neon sign burn out.</li><li>Sonny gets a call from a detective telling him about his father's shooting. He then tries to call Tom.</li><li>Sonny tells Mama about the shooting. He then goes into Vito's study, calls Tessio and tells him to prepare his men. He then tries to call Luca.</li><li>A quick shot of Michael driving, returning home after his father's shooting and Rocco offering to escort Michael into the house.</li><li>Michael brings Tom's wife Theresa into the study where Sonny and Tessio are. Sonny comforts her and tells them both to wait outside but Michael stays. They discuss with Michael whether Clemenza or Paulie was the traitor. Michael tries to talk Sonny out of going to war stating Vito would not want it. Then Tom returns home and hugs Theresa.</li><li>Immediately following is a quick shot of the Corleone compound that dissolves to the scene where they discuss their next course of action.</li><li>Rocco admires Clemenza's car but Clemenza complains that the bumpers are wooden due to the war effort. He then tells Rocco that he is to kill Paulie.</li><li>Clemenza has Paulie check the hideout spot. He then has Paulie make a stop so he can buy some cannoli and have a meal at a restaurant.</li><li>In Sicily, Michael and the bodyguards watch a Communist demonstration march.</li><li>While relaxing in the afternoon sun, Fabrizio begs Michael to bring him along to America when he returns.</li><li>Michael and his bodyguards visit his father's childhood home and find it abandoned.</li><li>After Connie hangs up the phone on Carlo's "girlfriend", she then confronts him in the shower. Then, Carlo orders her to make him dinner.</li><li>Bonasera is shown getting ready to return his favor to Don Vito. Bonasera tells his wife who is helping him get dressed that maybe he will be asked to be an accomplice to murder.</li><li>After the car bomb, Michael wakes up in bed surrounded by nurses and Don Tommasino. Michael tells Tommasino to find Fabrizio and he passes out.</li><li>Michael and Vito talk in the new garden after his return from Sicily. Michael takes responsibility for avenging the deaths of Sonny and Apollonia so Vito will not have to break his promise to the other Dons.</li><li>Additional dialogue when Michael removes Tom from his position as consigliere.</li><li>The final scene is Kay in a Catholic church lighting candles and praying.</li></ul>        <a href="alternateversions?tab=cz"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>

    <div class="article" id="titleUserReviewsTeaser">
        <h2>User Reviews</h2>
        <div class="user-comments">
                    <div class="tinystarbar" title="10/10">
                        <div style="width: 100px;"> </div>
                    </div>
                <span>
                    <strong>Initially, I wasn't a fan... but then I realised</strong>
                    <div class="comment-meta">
                        14 October 2006 | by <a href="/user/ur5347756/"
><span>mattrochman</span></a>
                        – <a href="/user/ur5347756/comments"
>See all my reviews</a>
                    </div>
                    <div>
                        <p>This is a masterpiece. A timeless masterpiece. Initially, I didn't like this film all that much - I found it rather over-hyped and boring. This was until the advent of DVD, which gave me the feature I needed for this sort of film: subtitles. Once I switched them on and heard (read) every last word of Brando's ramblings and other characters ramblings, I grew a true appreciation for this epic.<br/><br/>To make a true epic, you need all of three following ingredients working in near perfect harmony. For screenwriters who come across this, take the following pointers on board: 1) Contrasting Characters: Good films have some character distinction, but most fall rather flat because the core of each character is the same.<br/><br/>Of course, there are exceptions to rule (ie... where you want mono-tonal characters... aka matrix; or where you want outlandish contrasts... aka The Fifth Element), but ultimately, this is what makes films deep, meaningful and grand. Consider the contrasts between the Don's children. Michael is rather cool, rational and collected, whereas Sonny is more hot-headed, spontaneous and simple minded. But simply having these contrasts is not nearly enough. What you really need to do is to develop these characters - place them in situations - and then dwell on how their character impacts on the situation they're put in. The Godfather is a terrific example of how to pull this off. While many try to do this in screenplays, most lose the plot and create character obscurities that stretch credibility.<br/><br/>2) Transformation: The central character(s) must undergo a transformation, resulting in them being almost unrecognizable by the end of the film. By putting them into situations, the character's character must not only influence the outcome of the situation; it must also have a lasting impact on the character. Consider Michael at the wedding and compare that to the Michael we see at the end of the film. Again, many films try, but most fail because they come up with unreal (literally, not praisingly) or simply moronic transformations (eg, Wall Street).<br/><br/>3) Patience: Men in Black 2 was an astounding film for one simple reason - it was an entire film squashed into about 70 minutes. It was not much longer than an episode of ER or Buffy. I certainly hope the new goal of Hollywood isn't to make films as short as possible.<br/><br/>All the great ones spend time - time developing characters, family life, growth, patience with the story telling in general. This is the key (provided that the story isn't mind-numbingly boring). Dances with Wolves, Heat.. and so on are very patient but top-class films. While studios may be lukewarm on the idea of longer films, they are worth it if you have a ripper story to base it on.<br/><br/>I feel that this film has not dated all that much and has tremendous re-watch-ability.</p>
                    </div>
                </span>
                <hr />

    "dateCreated": "1999-05-07",
    "inLanguage": "English",
    "name": "The Greatest Film Ever Made",
    "reviewBody": "The original Godfather is a brilliant work. It is in a sense a voyeuristic delight, allowing us to see the mafia from the inside - we become part of the family. It single-handedly change the world\u0027s view of organized crime, and created a cast of sympathetic characters, none of whom have a shred of common morality. It was the highest grossing movie of its time and Brando created a cultural icon whose influence resonates as strong today as it did in 1972.\n\nAs extraordinary an achievement as this is, Part II is even better. It easily receives my nod as the best picture ever made. I have seen it at least 20 times, and each time its 200 minutes fly by.\n\nThe movie uses flashbacks to brilliantly weave two tales. The main story is the reign of Michael Corleone as the world\u0027s most powerful criminal. Now reaping the benefits of legalized gambling in Las Vegas, Michael is an evident billionaire with an iron fist on a world of treachery.\n\n Behind this, Director Francis Ford Coppola spins the tale of the rise of Michael\u0027s father, Vito, to the center of the New York mafia. It is these scenes that make the film a work of art. Without spoiling, I will simply say the Robert DeNiro as the young Vito is the best acting performance of all time, a role  for which he won a richly deserved Oscar.\n\nThe screenplay is full of delicious little underworld nuggets (\"Keep your friends close .....\", \"I don\u0027t want to kill everyone, just my enemies\"), while it blows a dense, twisted plot past you at a dizzying and merciless pace. The cinematography is depressing and atmospheric. The score continues in the eerie role of its predecessor, foretelling death and evil.\n\nAll of this makes the movie great and infinitely watchable. But it\u0027s what\u0027s deeper inside this film ... what it is really about ... that is its true genius.\n\nThe Godfather Part II is not really a movie about the mafia, it is a movie about a man\u0027s life long struggle. Michael controls a vast empire that is constantly slipping out of his hands. He grows increasingly distrustful and paranoid, and even shows signs that he hates his own life. Michael almost seems to resent the fact that he is a natural born crime lord, a man who puts the family business ahead of everything.\n\nThe great Don Michael Corleone can never come to terms with one simple fact.... his father\u0027s empire was built on love and respect, Michael\u0027s empire is built on fear and violent treachery.\n\nSee this movie. It\u0027s three-and-a-half hours very well spent.",

        <h2>Did You Know?</h2>
    <div id="trivia" class="txt-block">
        <h4>Trivia</h4>
    Unlike with the first film, <a href="/name/nm0000338">Francis Ford Coppola</a> was given nearly complete control over production. In his commentary, he said this resulted in a shoot that ran very smoothly despite multiple locations and two narratives running parallel within one film.        <a href="trivia"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>
                <hr />
     <div id="goofs"  class="txt-block">
        <h4>Goofs</h4>
Though the time-frame was the fifties, the fuselage style of the Cessna that landed was not produced until 1964.        <a href="trivia?tab=gf"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>   
                <hr />
    <div id="quotes" class="text-block">
        <h4>Quotes</h4>
[<span class="fine">first lines</span>]
<br /><span class="character">Title Card</span>:
The godfather was born Vito Andolini, in the town of Corleone in Sicily. In 1901 his father was murdered for an insult to the local Mafia chieftain. His older brother Paolo swore revenge and disappeared into the hills, leaving Vito, the only male heir, to stand with his mother at the funeral. He was nine years old.
<br />[<span class="fine">gunshots and screams</span>]
<br /><span class="character">Woman</span>:
[<span class="fine">subtitled from Italian</span>]
They've killed the boy! They've killed young Paolo! They've killed your son Paolo!
<br />        <a href="trivia?tab=qt"
class="nobr" >See more</a> »
    </div>
                <hr />
     <div id="crazyCredits"  class="txt-block">
        <h4>Crazy Credits</h4>
    This is the only Godfather film not to feature a standalone title screen against a black background. Instead, the title appears over Michael Corleone's chair after he gets up out of it.        <a href="trivia?tab=cz"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>   
                <hr />
     <div id="alternateVersions"  class="txt-block">
        <h4>Alternate Versions</h4>
In the German theatrical version, all Italian dialogs from the young Vito Corleone's scenes were dubbed into German, as well as the English and Spanish dialogs from Michael Corleone's scenes. The original Italian language for this footage has been only restored for the movie's DVD release in 2002.        <a href="alternateversions?tab=cz"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>

    <div class="article" id="titleUserReviewsTeaser">
        <h2>User Reviews</h2>
        <div class="user-comments">
                    <div class="tinystarbar" title="10/10">
                        <div style="width: 100px;"> </div>
                    </div>
                <span>
                    <strong>The Greatest Film Ever Made</strong>
                    <div class="comment-meta">
                        7 May 1999 | by <a href="/user/ur0200644/"
><span>DanB-4</span></a>
                        – <a href="/user/ur0200644/comments"
>See all my reviews</a>
                    </div>
                    <div>
                        <p>The original Godfather is a brilliant work. It is in a sense a voyeuristic delight, allowing us to see the mafia from the inside - we become part of the family. It single-handedly change the world's view of organized crime, and created a cast of sympathetic characters, none of whom have a shred of common morality. It was the highest grossing movie of its time and Brando created a cultural icon whose influence resonates as strong today as it did in 1972.<br/><br/>As extraordinary an achievement as this is, Part II is even better. It easily receives my nod as the best picture ever made. I have seen it at least 20 times, and each time its 200 minutes fly by.<br/><br/>The movie uses flashbacks to brilliantly weave two tales. The main story is the reign of Michael Corleone as the world's most powerful criminal. Now reaping the benefits of legalized gambling in Las Vegas, Michael is an evident billionaire with an iron fist on a world of treachery.<br/><br/>
Behind this, Director Francis Ford Coppola spins the tale of the rise of Michael's father, Vito, to the center of the New York mafia. It is these scenes that make the film a work of art. Without spoiling, I will simply say the Robert DeNiro as the young Vito is the best acting performance of all time, a role  for which he won a richly deserved Oscar.<br/><br/>The screenplay is full of delicious little underworld nuggets ("Keep your friends close .....", "I don't want to kill everyone, just my enemies"), while it blows a dense, twisted plot past you at a dizzying and merciless pace. The cinematography is depressing and atmospheric. The score continues in the eerie role of its predecessor, foretelling death and evil.<br/><br/>All of this makes the movie great and infinitely watchable. But it's what's deeper inside this film ... what it is really about ... that is its true genius.<br/><br/>The Godfather Part II is not really a movie about the mafia, it is a movie about a man's life long struggle. Michael controls a vast empire that is constantly slipping out of his hands. He grows increasingly distrustful and paranoid, and even shows signs that he hates his own life. Michael almost seems to resent the fact that he is a natural born crime lord, a man who puts the family business ahead of everything.<br/><br/>The great Don Michael Corleone can never come to terms with one simple fact.... his father's empire was built on love and respect, Michael's empire is built on fear and violent treachery.<br/><br/>See this movie. It's three-and-a-half hours very well spent.</p>
                    </div>
                </span>

        <h2>Storyline</h2>
        
        <div class="inline canwrap">
            <p>
                <span>    Set within a year after the events of Batman Begins (2005), Batman, Lieutenant James Gordon, and new District Attorney Harvey Dent successfully begin to round up the criminals that plague Gotham City, until a mysterious and sadistic criminal mastermind known only as "The Joker" appears in Gotham, creating a new wave of chaos. Batman's struggle against The Joker becomes deeply personal, forcing him to "confront everything he believes" and improve his technology to stop him. A love triangle develops between Bruce Wayne, Dent, and Rachel Dawes.</span>
                <em class="nobr">Written by
<a href="/search/title?plot_author=Leon%20Lombardi&view=simple&sort=alpha"
>Leon Lombardi</a></em>            </p>

    <div id="titleDidYouKnow" class="article">
    <span class=rightcornerlink >
            <a href="/register/login?why=edit"
rel="login">Edit</a>

        <h2>Did You Know?</h2>
    <div id="trivia" class="txt-block">
        <h4>Trivia</h4>
    All of the main action in this movie takes place over nine days and nights, by far the shortest time span of The Dark Knight trilogy (<a href="/title/tt0372784">Batman Begins</a> (2005) takes place over a few decades, and <a href="/title/tt1345836">The Dark Knight Rises</a> (2012), even when removing the flashbacks that elongate its time span to a few decades, still covers many months within the main action). The only scenes in this movie that are implied to take place outside of these nine days and nights are the brief flash-forwards in the final scene of Harvey Dent's funeral (which would probably not take place for at least one week) and Gordon breaking the bat signal. The "day" with the most screentime in the movie is the final day, which covers forty-eight minutes (a full third of the total runtime). Furthermore, unlike the other movies of the trilogy, which contain copious flashbacks, this movie only contains one flashback, when Harvey Dent remembers flipping his coin to Rachel while lying in his hospital bed. With that flashback, this movie not only becomes the only movie in the trilogy where Bruce Wayne does not have a flashback, but also the only movie where the content of the flashback references a previous scene within the movie's main action. The flashbacks of the other movies all either reference moments that take place outside of the movie's main action (a flashback to Wayne's childhood), or moments that, while being part of the main action, are shown for the first time in the flashback.        <a href="trivia"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>
                <hr />
     <div id="goofs"  class="txt-block">
        <h4>Goofs</h4>
(at around 1h 45 mins) When the Joker and Two-Face are in the hospital room, the Joker unstraps Two-Face's right hand and it falls to his side. In the next shot the hand is higher and partially back in the strap.        <a href="trivia?tab=gf"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>   
                <hr />
    <div id="quotes" class="text-block">
        <h4>Quotes</h4>
[<span class="fine">first lines</span>]
<br /><a href="/name/nm0325975/"
><span class="character">Grumpy</span></a>:
[<span class="fine">with Chuckles, picks up Bozo on the street</span>]
Three of a kind, let's do this!
<br /><a href="/name/nm1115978/"
><span class="character">Chuckles</span></a>:
Huh, that's it? Three guys?
<br /><a href="/name/nm0325975/"
><span class="character">Grumpy</span></a>:
Plus two guys on the roof. Every guy gets a share. Five shares is plenty.
<br /><a href="/name/nm1115978/"
><span class="character">Chuckles</span></a>:
*Six* shares. Don't forget the guy who planned the job.
<br /><a href="/name/nm0325975/"
><span class="character">Grumpy</span></a>:
If he thinks he can sit it out and still take a slice I know why they call him "The Joker".
<br /><a href="/name/nm2624644/"
><span class="character">Happy</span></a>:
[<span class="fine">up on the roof, breaking open the alarm box with Dopey</span>]
So why do they call him "the Joker"?
<br /><a href="/name/nm0832989/"
><span class="character">Dopey</span></a>:
I hear he wears makeup.
<br /><a href="/name/nm2624644/"
><span class="character">Happy</span></a>:
Makeup?
<br /><a href="/name/nm2624644/"
><span class="character">Happy</span></a>:
Yeah, to scare people. You know, ...
<br />                [...]<br />
        <a href="trivia?tab=qt"
class="nobr" >See more</a> »
    </div>
                <hr />
     <div id="crazyCredits"  class="txt-block">
        <h4>Crazy Credits</h4>
    The Warner Bros logo, Legendary Pictures logo and DC Comics logos are shaded dark blue.        <a href="trivia?tab=cz"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>   
                <hr />
     <div id="alternateVersions"  class="txt-block">
        <h4>Alternate Versions</h4>
The Blu-ray version of the movie has several of the big action scenes and high altitude photography scenes in ordinary 16:9 (1.78:1) widescreen ratio while the rest of the movie preserves the "scope" format (2.39:1). This is because these scenes were filmed in IMAX, whose format is 1.43:1, thus attempting to recreate the effect witnessed in IMAX theaters, as well as preserving as much of these shots as possible.        <a href="alternateversions?tab=cz"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>

                    <div>

  "description": "12 Angry Men is a movie starring Henry Fonda, Lee J. Cobb, and Martin Balsam. A jury holdout attempts to prevent a miscarriage of justice by forcing his colleagues to reconsider the evidence.",
  "datePublished": "1957-04-10",
  "keywords": "jury,dialogue driven,courtroom,single set production,trial",
  "aggregateRating": {
    "@type": "AggregateRating",
    "ratingCount": 651285,

  "review": {
    "@type": "Review",
    "itemReviewed": {
      "@type": "CreativeWork",
      "url": "/title/tt0050083/"
    },
    "author": {
      "@type": "Person",
      "name": "jomipira"
    },
    "dateCreated": "2003-09-01",
    "inLanguage": "English",
    "name": "Good script, great dialogs and a set of actors who would be the envy of the world",
    "reviewBody": "This is one of those movies where everything could go wrong. The story is as simple as it can be: 12 men are jurors on a open and shut murder trial, but one man thinks that another persons life deserves at least some thought on the matter and votes not guilty. From this point on we have 12 actors and a closed room. This could be the most boring film ever made. Lumet however is a master of mise-en-scene and provides a tense movie that keeps you locked on from the word \"go\". The dialogs are great and supported by incredibly talented actors. Joel Schumacher in Phone Booth needed to see this movie and draw a few ideas on how to make a character built, dialog driven movie. A must see for everyone.",
    "reviewRating": {

    }

        <h2>Storyline</h2>
        
        <div class="inline canwrap">
            <p>
                <span>    The defense and the prosecution have rested and the jury is filing into the jury room to decide if a young man is guilty or innocent of murdering his father. What begins as an open-and-shut case of murder soon becomes a detective story that presents a succession of clues creating doubt, and a mini-drama of each of the jurors' prejudices and preconceptions about the trial, the accused, and each other. Based on the play, all of the action takes place on the stage of the jury room.</span>
                <em class="nobr">Written by
<a href="/search/title?plot_author=pjk%20%3CPETESID%40VNET.IBM.COM%3E&view=simple&sort=alpha"

    <div class="article" id="titleUserReviewsTeaser">
        <h2>User Reviews</h2>
        <div class="user-comments">
                    <div class="tinystarbar" title="9/10">
                        <div style="width: 90px;"> </div>
                    </div>
                <span>
                    <strong>Good script, great dialogs and a set of actors who would be the envy of the world</strong>
                    <div class="comment-meta">
                        1 September 2003 | by <a href="/user/ur0645286/"
><span>jomipira</span></a>
                        – <a href="/user/ur0645286/comments"
>See all my reviews</a>
                    </div>
                    <div>
                        <p>This is one of those movies where everything could go wrong. The story is as simple as it can be: 12 men are jurors on a open and shut murder trial, but one man thinks that another persons life deserves at least some thought on the matter and votes not guilty. From this point on we have 12 actors and a closed room. This could be the most boring film ever made. Lumet however is a master of mise-en-scene and provides a tense movie that keeps you locked on from the word "go". The dialogs are great and supported by incredibly talented actors. Joel Schumacher in Phone Booth needed to see this movie and draw a few ideas on how to make a character built, dialog driven movie. A must see for everyone.</p>
                    </div>
                </span>

        <h2>Storyline</h2>
        
        <div class="inline canwrap">
            <p>
                <span>    Oskar Schindler is a vain and greedy German businessman who becomes an unlikely humanitarian amid the barbaric German Nazi reign when he feels compelled to turn his factory into a refuge for Jews. Based on the true story of Oskar Schindler who managed to save about 1100 Jews from being gassed at the Auschwitz concentration camp, it is a testament to the good in all of us.</span>
                <em class="nobr">Written by
<a href="/search/title?plot_author=Harald%20Mayr%20%3Cmarvin%40bike.augusta.de%3E&view=simple&sort=alpha"
>Harald Mayr <marvin@bike.augusta.de></a></em>            </p>
        </div>

    <span class=rightcornerlink >
            <a href="/register/login?why=edit"
rel="login">Edit</a>
    </span>
        <h2>Did You Know?</h2>
    <div id="trivia" class="txt-block">
        <h4>Trivia</h4>
    <a href="/name/nm0000229">Steven Spielberg</a> actively pursued the project when he noticed the increasing antisemitism and Neo-Nazism in the 1990s, basically the same sentiments that had led to the Holocaust in the first place. He was also horrified that Holocaust deniers were being taken increasingly serious in the media. His resolve to make the film was further strengthened when studio executives asked him why he didn't simply make a donation of some sort, rather than wasting everyone's time and money on a depressing film.        <a href="trivia"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>
                <hr />
     <div id="goofs"  class="txt-block">
        <h4>Goofs</h4>
The Doctor who poisons his patient in an act of mercy killing is first seen covered in blood scrambling to get the poison from a pharmacy. Moments later he is seen in a perfectly clean identical coat when he is distributing the poison. A bit later he is seen carrying a wounded woman who is subsequently shot by an SS man, the former bleeding out on the doctor.        <a href="trivia?tab=gf"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>   
                <hr />
    <div id="quotes" class="text-block">
        <h4>Quotes</h4>
[<span class="fine">first lines</span>]
<br />[<span class="fine">a Hebrew prayer is chanted, followed by a flashback to 1940s Poland</span>]
<br /><span class="character">Krakow registrar</span>:
Name?
<br />        <a href="trivia?tab=qt"
class="nobr" >See more</a> »
    </div>
                <hr />
     <div id="crazyCredits"  class="txt-block">
        <h4>Crazy Credits</h4>
    The end credits are shot in black and white.<br /><br />The Amblin Entertainment logo is absent and in its place instead is the credit: "From Amblin Entertainment".<br /><br />The MPAA Rated R logo at the end does not have the regular blue background and is shown over the black screen.        <a href="trivia?tab=cz"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>   
                <hr />
     <div id="alternateVersions"  class="txt-block">
        <h4>Alternate Versions</h4>
In an unprecedented move, when this film was broadcast on US television by NBC in 1997, it was, at <a href="/name/nm0000229/">Steven Spielberg</a>'s insistence, shown nearly uncensored (a sex scene was slightly edited) with all violence and nudity intact. It was the first program to air with the then new "TV-M" (now "TV-MA") rating. See also: <a href="/title/tt0120815/">Saving Private Ryan</a>.        <a href="alternateversions?tab=cz"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>   
                <hr />

class="nobr" >See more</a> »

        <h2>User Reviews</h2>
        <div class="user-comments">
                <span>
                    <strong>Moving and timeless</strong>
                    <div class="comment-meta">
                        14 May 2000 | by <a href="/user/ur0710287/"
><span>shelley_uk</span></a>
                        – <a href="/user/ur0710287/comments"
>See all my reviews</a>
                    </div>
                    <div>
                        <p>I can honestly say that this is one of the truly great films. The way it creates and image of one of the most tragic periods of human history both educates and moves us as well as providing a fitting testament to those who died, and because it deals with a subject which will never be forgotten it is a film which will always be relevant, thus making it a timeless work which throughly deserves the recognition that it received.</p>
                    </div>
                </span>

  "review": {
    "@type": "Review",
    "itemReviewed": {

    "dateCreated": "2007-11-30",
    "inLanguage": "English",
    "name": "Part 3:  It\u0027s Not Really the Thought that Counts",
    "reviewBody": "Just as Peter Jackson felt that LOTR had to be made as one large, three-part, cinematic piece, I decided to write my IMDb review of all three movies as a single, multi-part essay. Click on my screen-name and hit \"Chronological\" to view my reviews of the Fellowship and Two Towers. I make no guarantees about the quality and consistence of my review, but I do guarantee that these three films offer very high and very consistent quality from beginning to end. The acting, cinematography, art, and direction simply can not be beat.\n\nWhich of the three movies is my favorite varies with my mood  and the same holds true for Tolkien\u0027s books. When I am immersed in the story, ROTK is my favorite. When I simply want to have fun with the whole experience, I love Fellowship. And when I want something intense, evocative and thoughtful, I go for the Two Towers.\n\nFrodo, Sam and Golem are on their way to Mount Doom and their bodies, nerves, and relationships have borne the greatest burden on middle earth. The rest of the fellowship is rallying to the defense of Minas Tirith, and preparing for even more deadly battles to come.\n\nThe heroism and romance are incredibly moving - when was the last time you saw an entire audience leaving a theater after a fantasy movie rubbing their eyes? The sets are breathtaking - even moreso than in the previous two films.\n\nThe casting and acting are superb.\n\nThe film delivers at every level and is the jewel in the trilogy\u0027s well-earned crown.\n\nReturn of the King offers a resolution of all of the major story arcs in LOTR. As with the classic Tolkien trilogy, however, you may be able to predict some of what will occur, but never all of it and you\u0027ll never guess how you will get there. The same fatalistic and paradoxically unpredictable feeling of Tolkien\u0027s grand plots is present throughout ROTK especially. The major theme in ROTK, however, is the varied ways and means of heroism  both intentional and unintended, and Tolkien\u0027s examination of sacrifice and heroism is as inspiring as it is subtle. Amazingly, it all comes through in the films.\n\nEven more than the previous two films, Jackson and his writers took liberties with the story-line. Like the others, however, this serves the film better than simple adaptation from one medium to another. By reordering some of the chronology and adding scenes and plot devices which are consistent with Tolkien\u0027s world and characterizations, the film-makers actually do a better job of preserving the concepts and themes of the story than they could have with a pure adaptation. The lengthy epilogue in Tolkien\u0027s book is greatly reduced, reordered, and somewhat changed in order to work in the film. Some parts actually appear very early in ROTK. And some aspects of Tolkien\u0027s epilogue are disclosed in the Two Towers, though not directly depicted. But all of the really important components of the epilogue are, at least strongly implied if not well illustrated in ROTK.",

        <h2>Did You Know?</h2>
    <div id="trivia" class="txt-block">
        <h4>Trivia</h4>
    <a href="/name/nm0101710">Billy Boyd</a>'s singing scene largely came about because co-writer <a href="/name/nm0101991">Philippa Boyens</a> went for a night out at a karaoke bar with the younger male cast members, and she was very struck by the quality of his voice. Remembering that Denethor asks Pippin to sing him a song when Faramir heads off to war, she resurrected the lyrics from the novel; where it is actually sung by all four hobbits in the Fellowship of the Ring, and Boyd came up with the tune for it.        <a href="trivia"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>
                <hr />
     <div id="goofs"  class="txt-block">

As Frodo enters Shelob's lair with Gollum, Frodo can be seen visibly favoring his right foot, but in the next shot, he is walking normally.        <a href="trivia?tab=gf"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>

    There's a text written in maori: Me mahara tonu taatou nga Uri- aapakura noo tuaanuku nei, noo te waaotuu te tu kekehua ana o ngaa Eldarin kua  hohouu mai i te Uru-moana. Which is in english: Let us dedicate our memories to the spirits  of the Eldar who came to us from the Ocean that lies to the West.        <a href="trivia?tab=cz"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>

    <div class="article" id="titleUserReviewsTeaser">
        <h2>User Reviews</h2>
        <div class="user-comments">
                    <div class="tinystarbar" title="10/10">
                        <div style="width: 100px;"> </div>
                    </div>
                <span>
                    <strong>Part 3:  It's Not Really the Thought that Counts</strong>
                    <div class="comment-meta">
                        30 November 2007 | by <a href="/user/ur3824745/"
><span>mstomaso</span></a>
                        – <a href="/user/ur3824745/comments"
>See all my reviews</a>
                    </div>
                    <div>
                        <p>Just as Peter Jackson felt that LOTR had to be made as one large, three-part, cinematic piece, I decided to write my IMDb review of all three movies as a single, multi-part essay. Click on my screen-name and hit "Chronological" to view my reviews of the Fellowship and Two Towers. I make no guarantees about the quality and consistence of my review, but I do guarantee that these three films offer very high and very consistent quality from beginning to end. The acting, cinematography, art, and direction simply can not be beat.<br/><br/>Which of the three movies is my favorite varies with my mood  and the same holds true for Tolkien's books. When I am immersed in the story, ROTK is my favorite. When I simply want to have fun with the whole experience, I love Fellowship. And when I want something intense, evocative and thoughtful, I go for the Two Towers.<br/><br/>Frodo, Sam and Golem are on their way to Mount Doom and their bodies, nerves, and relationships have borne the greatest burden on middle earth. The rest of the fellowship is rallying to the defense of Minas Tirith, and preparing for even more deadly battles to come.<br/><br/>The heroism and romance are incredibly moving - when was the last time you saw an entire audience leaving a theater after a fantasy movie rubbing their eyes? The sets are breathtaking - even moreso than in the previous two films.<br/><br/>The casting and acting are superb.<br/><br/>The film delivers at every level and is the jewel in the trilogy's well-earned crown.<br/><br/>Return of the King offers a resolution of all of the major story arcs in LOTR. As with the classic Tolkien trilogy, however, you may be able to predict some of what will occur, but never all of it and you'll never guess how you will get there. The same fatalistic and paradoxically unpredictable feeling of Tolkien's grand plots is present throughout ROTK especially. The major theme in ROTK, however, is the varied ways and means of heroism  both intentional and unintended, and Tolkien's examination of sacrifice and heroism is as inspiring as it is subtle. Amazingly, it all comes through in the films.<br/><br/>Even more than the previous two films, Jackson and his writers took liberties with the story-line. Like the others, however, this serves the film better than simple adaptation from one medium to another. By reordering some of the chronology and adding scenes and plot devices which are consistent with Tolkien's world and characterizations, the film-makers actually do a better job of preserving the concepts and themes of the story than they could have with a pure adaptation. The lengthy epilogue in Tolkien's book is greatly reduced, reordered, and somewhat changed in order to work in the film. Some parts actually appear very early in ROTK. And some aspects of Tolkien's epilogue are disclosed in the Two Towers, though not directly depicted. But all of the really important components of the epilogue are, at least strongly implied if not well illustrated in ROTK.</p>
                    </div>
                </span>

  "datePublished": "1994-09-10",
  "keywords": "nonlinear timeline,overdose,drug overdose,black comedy,bondage",

    "@type": "AggregateRating",
    "ratingCount": 1747206,
    "bestRating": "10.0",

    "itemReviewed": {

    "author": {
      "@type": "Person",
      "name": "verbal-15"
    },
    "dateCreated": "1998-08-02",
    "inLanguage": "English",
    "name": "Hands down, the best film of the \u002790s.",
    "reviewBody": "Pulp Fiction, despite borrowing from just about every movie ever made, is the most invigorating cinema experience a filmgoer can ever hope for. Its hodgepodge of violence, mayhem, and generally deviant behavior is an assault on the senses, not to mention political correctness. However, despite all the film\u0027s cleverness and style, it hinges on the performance put forth by Samuel L. Jackson as Jules. The fact that he was denied an Oscar is a downright shame. Martin Landau, the best supporting actor winner that year, was terrific and funny in Ed Wood, but Jackson was perhaps the most commanding screen presence in film history as the bible-quoting, godfearing hitman. The last scene in the coffee shop with Tim Roth still sends chills down my spine, no matter how many times I\u0027ve seen it. Rumors of a prequel involving Jules and Vincent (John Travolta) have been floating around lately. If Quentin Tarantino wishes to regain the fans he lost with the dissapointing (but still pretty good) Jackie Brown, he should get to work right away. I\u0027ll be the first in line to see the finished product."
  },

        <h2>Storyline</h2>
        
        <div class="inline canwrap">
            <p>
                <span>    Jules Winnfield (<a href="/name/nm0000168">Samuel L. Jackson</a>) and Vincent Vega (<a href="/name/nm0000237">John Travolta</a>) are two hit men who are out to retrieve a suitcase stolen from their employer, mob boss Marsellus Wallace (<a href="/name/nm0000609">Ving Rhames</a>). Wallace has also asked Vincent to take his wife Mia (<a href="/name/nm0000235">Uma Thurman</a>) out a few days later when Wallace himself will be out of town. Butch Coolidge (<a href="/name/nm0000246">Bruce Willis</a>) is an aging boxer who is paid by Wallace to lose his fight. The lives of these seemingly unrelated people are woven together comprising of a series of funny, bizarre and uncalled-for incidents.</span>
                <em class="nobr">Written by
<a href="/search/title?plot_author=Soumitra&view=simple&sort=alpha"
>Soumitra</a></em>            </p>

        <h2>Did You Know?</h2>
    <div id="trivia" class="txt-block">
        <h4>Trivia</h4>
    <a href="/name/nm0000235">Uma Thurman</a> originally turned down the role of Mia Wallace. <a href="/name/nm0000233">Quentin Tarantino</a> was so desperate to have her as Mia, he ended up reading her the script over the phone, finally convincing her to take on the role.        <a href="trivia"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>
                <hr />
     <div id="goofs"  class="txt-block">
        <h4>Goofs</h4>
(at around 1h 55 mins) After Vincent shoots Marvin the frame switches to the front seat and Vincent's gun is shown without a clip inserted.        <a href="trivia?tab=gf"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>   
                <hr />
    <div id="quotes" class="text-block">
        <h4>Quotes</h4>
[<span class="fine">first lines</span>]
<br /><a href="/name/nm0000619/"
><span class="character">Pumpkin</span></a>:
Forget it. Too risky. I'm through doing that shit.
<br /><a href="/name/nm0001625/"
><span class="character">Yolanda</span></a>:
You always say that. That same thing every time, "I'm through, never again, too dangerous".
<br /><a href="/name/nm0000619/"
><span class="character">Pumpkin</span></a>:
I know that's what I always say. I'm always right, too.
<br /><a href="/name/nm0001625/"
><span class="character">Yolanda</span></a>:
But you forget about it in a day or two.
<br /><a href="/name/nm0000619/"
><span class="character">Pumpkin</span></a>:
Yeah, well the days of me forgetting are over, and the days of me remembering have just begun.
<br />        <a href="trivia?tab=qt"
class="nobr" >See more</a> »
    </div>

     <div id="crazyCredits"  class="txt-block">
        <h4>Crazy Credits</h4>
    The opening credits end with Produced by Lawrence Bender. Usually movies end opening credits with the Director's credit, however Written and Directed by Quentin Tarantino starts the end credits.        <a href="trivia?tab=cz"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>

    <div class="article" id="titleUserReviewsTeaser">
        <h2>User Reviews</h2>
        <div class="user-comments">
                <span>
                    <strong>Hands down, the best film of the '90s.</strong>
                    <div class="comment-meta">
                        2 August 1998 | by <a href="/user/ur0089353/"
><span>verbal-15</span></a>
                        – <a href="/user/ur0089353/comments"
>See all my reviews</a>
                    </div>
                    <div>
                        <p>Pulp Fiction, despite borrowing from just about every movie ever made, is the most invigorating cinema experience a filmgoer can ever hope for. Its hodgepodge of violence, mayhem, and generally deviant behavior is an assault on the senses, not to mention political correctness. However, despite all the film's cleverness and style, it hinges on the performance put forth by Samuel L. Jackson as Jules. The fact that he was denied an Oscar is a downright shame. Martin Landau, the best supporting actor winner that year, was terrific and funny in Ed Wood, but Jackson was perhaps the most commanding screen presence in film history as the bible-quoting, godfearing hitman. The last scene in the coffee shop with Tim Roth still sends chills down my spine, no matter how many times I've seen it. Rumors of a prequel involving Jules and Vincent (John Travolta) have been floating around lately. If Quentin Tarantino wishes to regain the fans he lost with the dissapointing (but still pretty good) Jackie Brown, he should get to work right away. I'll be the first in line to see the finished product.</p>
                    </div>
                </span>

    "name": "For a girl who doesn\u0027t enjoy westerns much, this was one of the greatest films ever!",
    "reviewBody": "Gosh, The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly, I finally saw this film! Who hasn\u0027t heard of it? First off, may I say that Clint Eastwood... what a hottie in his day! :D Sorry, had to get that off my chest. Sergio Leone from what I understood was a huge western film fanatic and in the 60\u0027s pretty much most folks had moved onto other genre\u0027s. I mean, I would agree that most western\u0027s are pretty much the same and stereotypical.\n\nSergio however took a story and added some elements to it such as comedy, drama, and war. The story flows so well and just compliments all of it\u0027s characters. By far my favorite character was The Good, played by Clint. He is a bounty hunter who captures The Ugly numerous times just to free him before every hanging and splits the winnings with him. When they learn of a coffin in the desert that has $200,000, they go for it. Of course we have the Bad who is a ruthless killer who also wants in on the doe.\n\nThe Good, The Bad, and The Ugly is a terrific film and I thank all the IMDb users for their useful comments and that pushed me to finally rent this western classic. Let\u0027s give it up for Sergio! \n\n10/10",

        <h2>Storyline</h2>
        
        <div class="inline canwrap">
            <p>
                <span>    Blondie (The Good) (Clint Eastwood) is a professional gunslinger who is out trying to earn a few dollars. Angel Eyes (The Bad) (Lee Van Cleef) is a hitman who always commits to a task and sees it through, as long as he is paid to do so. And Tuco (The Ugly) (Eli Wallach) is a wanted outlaw trying to take care of his own hide. Tuco and Blondie share a partnership together making money off of Tuco's bounty, but when Blondie unties the partnership, Tuco tries to hunt down Blondie. When Blondie and Tuco come across a horse carriage loaded with dead bodies, they soon learn from the only survivor, Bill Carson (Antonio Casale), that he and a few other men have buried a stash of gold in a cemetery. Unfortunately, Carson dies and Tuco only finds out the name of the cemetery, while Blondie finds out the name on the grave. Now the two must keep each other alive in order to find the gold. Angel Eyes (who had been looking for Bill Carson) discovers that Tuco and Blondie met with Carson and knows ...</span>
                <em class="nobr">Written by
<a href="/search/title?plot_author=Jeremy%20Thomson&view=simple&sort=alpha"
>Jeremy Thomson</a></em>            </p>

        <h2>Did You Know?</h2>
    <div id="trivia" class="txt-block">
        <h4>Trivia</h4>
    Leone loved the look of intense blue eyes on his actors, especially those with dark complexions. It added to the drama and incongruity of his stories, which deconstructed the conventional approach to good vs evil in the western.        <a href="trivia"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>
                <hr />
     <div id="goofs"  class="txt-block">
        <h4>Goofs</h4>
When the two armies battle at the bridge, the Confederates are using the flag with the blue criss-cross on the red field. This is not the Confederate national flag, rather it is the banner of Gen. Robert E. Lee's Army of Northern Virginia. It would have been in battles in the east, not in the west.        <a href="trivia?tab=gf"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>   
                <hr />

You're... from Baker?
<br />[<span class="fine">Angel Eyes is silent, eating a bowl of stew and staring at him</span>]
<br /><a href="/name/nm0143030/"
><span class="character">Stevens</span></a>:
Tell Baker that I told him all that I know already and I want to live in peace, understand? That it's no use to go on tormenting me! I know nothing at all about that case of coins.
<br />[<span class="fine">Angel Eyes stops eating and looks interested</span>]
<br /><a href="/name/nm0143030/"
><span class="character">Stevens</span></a>:
Now that gold has disappeared, but if he'd listened we could have avoided this altogether. I went to the Army court; there were no witnesses. They couldn't uncover any more....
<br />

class="nobr" >See more</a> »

    <div class="article" id="titleUserReviewsTeaser">
        <h2>User Reviews</h2>
        <div class="user-comments">
                    <div class="tinystarbar" title="10/10">
                        <div style="width: 100px;"> </div>
                    </div>
                <span>
                    <strong>For a girl who doesn't enjoy westerns much, this was one of the greatest films ever!</strong>
                    <div class="comment-meta">
                        29 June 2006 | by <a href="/user/ur1293485/"
><span>Smells_Like_Cheese</span></a>
                        – <a href="/user/ur1293485/comments"
>See all my reviews</a>
                    </div>
                    <div>
                        <p>Gosh, The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly, I finally saw this film! Who hasn't heard of it? First off, may I say that Clint Eastwood... what a hottie in his day! :D Sorry, had to get that off my chest. Sergio Leone from what I understood was a huge western film fanatic and in the 60's pretty much most folks had moved onto other genre's. I mean, I would agree that most western's are pretty much the same and stereotypical.<br/><br/>Sergio however took a story and added some elements to it such as comedy, drama, and war. The story flows so well and just compliments all of it's characters. By far my favorite character was The Good, played by Clint. He is a bounty hunter who captures The Ugly numerous times just to free him before every hanging and splits the winnings with him. When they learn of a coffin in the desert that has $200,000, they go for it. Of course we have the Bad who is a ruthless killer who also wants in on the doe.<br/><br/>The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly is a terrific film and I thank all the IMDb users for their useful comments and that pushed me to finally rent this western classic. Let's give it up for Sergio! <br/><br/>10/10</p>
                    </div>
                </span>

        <h2>Storyline</h2>
        
        <div class="inline canwrap">
            <p>
                <span>    An ancient Ring thought lost for centuries has been found, and through a strange twist of fate has been given to a small Hobbit named Frodo. When Gandalf discovers the Ring is in fact the One Ring of the Dark Lord Sauron, Frodo must make an epic quest to the Cracks of Doom in order to destroy it. However, he does not go alone. He is joined by Gandalf, Legolas the elf, Gimli the Dwarf, Aragorn, Boromir, and his three Hobbit friends Merry, Pippin, and Samwise. Through mountains, snow, darkness, forests, rivers and plains, facing evil and danger at every corner the Fellowship of the Ring must go. Their quest to destroy the One Ring is the only hope for the end of the Dark Lords reign.</span>
                <em class="nobr">Written by
<a href="/search/title?plot_author=Paul%20Twomey%20%3Ctoomsp%40hotmail.com%3E&view=simple&sort=alpha"
>Paul Twomey <toomsp@hotmail.com></a></em>            </p>

        <h2>Did You Know?</h2>
    <div id="trivia" class="txt-block">
        <h4>Trivia</h4>
    Legolas' arrows in the final battle are computer generated. It would have been physically impossible for even the most gifted archer to fire off so many arrows so quickly.        <a href="trivia"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>
                <hr />
     <div id="goofs"  class="txt-block">
        <h4>Goofs</h4>
After Gimli shatters his axe when attempting to destroy the Ring during the Council of Elrond, the axe shards can be seen surrounding the unharmed Ring, some of them quite close. In all of the subsequent close-up shots of the Ring, however, the axe shards aren't visible near the Ring or in its wide reflection.        <a href="trivia?tab=gf"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>   
                <hr />
    <div id="quotes" class="text-block">
        <h4>Quotes</h4>
[<span class="fine">first lines</span>]
<br /><a href="/name/nm0000949/"
><span class="character">Galadriel</span></a>:
The world is changed. I feel it in the water. I feel it in the earth. I smell it in the air. Much that once was is lost, for none now live who remember it. It began with the forging of the Great Rings. Three were given to the Elves, immortal, wisest and fairest of all beings. Seven to the Dwarf lords, great miners and craftsmen of the mountain halls. And nine, nine rings were gifted to the race of Men, who, above all else, desire power. But they were, all of them, deceived, for ...
<br />                
        <a href="trivia?tab=qt"
class="nobr" >See more</a> »
    </div>
                <hr />
     <div id="crazyCredits"  class="txt-block">
        <h4>Crazy Credits</h4>
    There are no opening credits after the title has been shown.        <a href="trivia?tab=cz"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>   
                <hr />
     <div id="alternateVersions"  class="txt-block">
        <h4>Alternate Versions</h4>
In the extended version there is actually a line missing. In the very beginning of the movie Gandalf mentions Hobbits as being ignored, thing of which he is most thankful; this line is not in the extended DVD version.        <a href="alternateversions?tab=cz"
class="nobr" >See more</a>  »
    </div>

                    <div>
                        <p>It is my firm belief that the standard versions of The Lord of the Rings should be jettisoned in favour of the extended editions universally.
